info.game_comments:
2016 Power Players Week game 1.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: Back in the 1st century B.C., the Acta Diurna was the daily news sheet of this ancient republic

(2, 1).clue: "A plain near to a port in Denmark" is a setting in this play

(3, 1).clue: This word is insulting when used to mean "a German", but is OK as a shorter word for a cabbage dish

(5, 1).clue: In 1934 this A.L. park got a new left field wall; in 1947 that wall was painted green to match the rest of the park

(6, 1).clue: Go go this mechanical contraption, thingamajig or doohickey

(1, 2).clue: This 19h century publisher was no prize; his New York World was synonymous with yellow journalism

(2, 2).clue: It's the first country mentioned in "Macbeth"

(3, 2).clue: The "B" in the name of this maker of cars like the M2 & X5 refers to Bavaria

(5, 2).clue: The first triple in this park was April 17, 1992, courtesy of Cal Ripken Jr.

(6, 2).clue: Type of general just below major general

(1, 3).clue: Londoners have been getting their news from this paper at all hours since 1788

(2, 3).clue: "The isle is full of noises", says Caliban in this play

(5, 3).clue: It only became the "Friendly Confines" for night games in 1988; it was the last ballpark to install lights

(6, 3).clue: "Insect" term for a person who persistently annoys others with criticism

(1, 4).clue: In 1735 a jury ruled that stories in the New York Weekly Journal were factual, so John Peter Zenger was acquitted of this

(2, 4).clue: This "Tale" takes place in Sicilia & Bohemia

(5, 4).clue: Built as the centerpiece of the 1996 Summer Olympics, it was converted for baseball after the Games

(6, 4).clue: In a musical this Scottish village awakens every 100 years

(1, 5).clue: freep.com is the website of this paper, a Michigan institution since 1835

(2, 5).clue: Part of "The Taming of the Shrew" is set at this tamer's country house

(5, 5).clue: A 1963 Mickey Mantle home run hit the upper deck of this stadium & bounced back nearly to second base

(6, 5).clue: 8-letter person who moves about aimlessly from one social activity to another

(1, 1).clue: In 2016 he won a Grammy Award for the audio version of his memoir "A Full Life: Reflections at Ninety"

(2, 1).clue: This city's Royal Danish Ballet debuted "The Whims of Cupid and the Ballet Master" in 1786 & it's still being danced today

(3, 1).clue: When Miss Colombia was not the No. 1 answer, the Miss Universe emcee & "Family Feud" host had to correct himself

(4, 1).clue: Term for a musical group of two

(5, 1).clue: Sri Lanka is the world's leading exporter of these leaves that make a hot beverage

(6, 1).clue: Gal Gadot as this character brought some Amazon estrogen to 2016's "Batman v. Superman"

(1, 2).clue: The face of this WWI-era prez was on the old $100,000 note, never used by the public

(2, 2).clue: The main characters of "Fancy Free" are the "three" these

(3, 2).clue: Between 2001 & 2013 this Italian landmark recovered nearly one inch of its vertical tilt

(4, 2).clue: I'm not superstitious, but I do know triskadekaphobia is fear of this number

(5, 2).clue: Monaco has the world's lowest of these, so there aren't enough little Monegasques to keep up the population

(6, 2).clue: He had his "Cher" of success as a singer of "I Got You Babe" before going to Congress

(1, 3).clue: His memorial at Arlington mentions that he was both president & Chief Justice of the United States

(2, 3).clue: A 1972 ballet was based on (& named for) the "Tales of" this German author

(3, 3).clue: Okay, you were right--my getting this haircut made famous by Mr. T in the '80s was a mistake

(4, 3).clue: Bruno Mars & Travie McCoy cashed in singing "I wanna be" this type of rich guy; "buy all the things I never had"

(5, 3).clue: More than 50 gold medals make this nation the leader in world curling championships for both men & women

(6, 3).clue: This Jim McMahon team hadn't won the title yet when they released "The Super Bowl Shuffle" in 1985

(1, 4).clue: He was the only president who had served as a 5-star general

(3, 4).clue: On Nov. 3, 1948 the Chicago Daily Tribune made a slight error on the front page--this man did not defeat Truman

(4, 4).clue: The man who wrote "O Little Town Of Bethlehem" led 2 churches named for this trio, Father, Son & Holy Spirit

(5, 4).clue: These 2 neighboring Middle East countries share the lowest elevation on land, about 1,300 feet below sea level

(6, 4).clue: The Bee Gees were doing this kind of "Talkin'" in a No. 1 hit

(1, 5).clue: Millard Fillmore was the last member of this political party to serve as president

(3, 5).clue: A correction is a drop in the value of a stock & can signal this type of animal-named market

(4, 5).clue: These large muscles at the front of the thigh take their name in part from the Latin for "four"

(5, 5).clue: This country of many islands has more Muslims than any other

(6, 5).clue: This director's films like "Jungle Fever" won him  special Academy Award in a 2015 ceremony

(0, 0).clue: Officials called tribunes sat at Rome's Senate door & if they didn't like what was going on, shouted this Latin word
